en: The good king Dharmagavesī (the Bodhisattva in a previous life) has a great desire to hear Dharma teaching and asked his ministers to proclaim throughout his kingdom that if anyone could teach him Dharma there would be a great reward.

Hearing of the king’s desire, Śakra—always up to mischief it seems!—decided to test his resolve. He took on a disguise as a yakṣa and spoke just one verse, which the king rejoiced in: ‘One should live by Dhamma, with good conduct, not with bad conduct, living by Dhamma one lives at ease in this world and the next.’ (cf. Dhp 169)

When the king asked him to continue he told him he would if the king would tend a fire for seven days and nights and at the end of that time throw himself into it. The king, of course, agreed, and, after crowning his son king, did as requested. As he threw himself into the fire it turned into a lotus pool.

The king then recited this verse: ‘This ember-pan, fearsome like a fiery torch, I fall into it for the sake of the Dharma, determined and unconcerned for life. Through the power of my merit the fire-pan will be lovely, (like) a lotus pond filled with lotuses that has cool sandalwood infused in its water.’

The king then jumped into the fire, but as he did so it was transformed into a lotus pond and the king was unhurt. Śakra then showed his real form and recited again the first verse, which the king caused to be recited throughout his kingdom.
id: Raja Dharmagavesī yang bajik (Bodhisattwa dalam kehidupan lampau) punya hasrat besar untuk mendengarkan ajaran Dharma dan meminta para menterinya untuk menyatakan di seluruh kerajaannya bahwa jika ada orang yang bisa mengajarinya Dharma, akan ada hadiah besar.

Mendengar hasrat raja, Śakra—sepertinya selalu usil!—memutuskan untuk menguji tekadnya. Ia menyamar sebagai yaksa dan hanya mengucap satu syair, yang membuat raja bersukacita: ‘Orang seharusnya hidup sesuai Dhamma, dengan perilaku baik, tidak dengan perilaku buruk; hidup sesuai Dhamma, orang hidup bahagia di dunia ini dan di dunia selanjutnya.’ (bandingkan dengan Dhp 169)

Ketika raja meminta Śakra untuk melanjutkan, Śakra berkata kepada raja bahwa ia akan melakukannya jika raja menyalakan api selama tujuh hari dan malam, dan pada akhir waktu itu raja menerjunkan diri ke dalam api. Raja, tentu saja, setuju, dan, setelah memahkotai putranya, melakukan yang diminta. Ketika ia terjun ke dalam api, api berubah menjadi kolam teratai.

Raja kemudian mendaras syair ini: ‘Wajan bara ini, menakutkan seperti obor api, aku jatuh ke dalamnya demi Dharma, bertekad dan tak peduli akan hidup. Melalui kekuatan kebajikanku, wajan bara akan menjadi indah, (seperti) kolam teratai yang diisi dengan teratai yang punya kayu cendana dingin meresap ke dalam airnya.’

Raja lalu melompat ke dalam api, tetapi saat ia melakukannya, api berubah menjadi kolam teratai dan raja tak terluka. Śakra kemudian menampakkan wujud aslinya dan mendaras kembali syair pertama, yang kemudian raja daraskan di seluruh kerajaannya.

en: The king, having a great desire to hear Dharma, assembled his ministers and gave a great reward to be offered throughout his kingdom to anyone who could teach him Dharma.

The king sits with his consort on a raised platform on the right. The king is marked as the Bodhisattva by the halo behind his head. In front of them one man holds a money-bag, while others carry away a treasure chest, which presumably is the reward the king will give for hearing the Dharma.
id: Raja, yang punya hasrat besar untuk mendengarkan Dharma, mengumpulkan para menterinya dan memberikan hadiah besar untuk ditawarkan di seluruh kerajaannya kepada siapa pun yang bisa mengajarinya Dharma.

Raja duduk dengan permaisurinya di panggung tinggi di kanan. Raja ditandai sebagai Bodhisattwa dengan aura di belakang kepalanya. Di depan mereka satu orang memegang kantong uang, sementara yang lain membawa peti harta, yang kemungkinan hadiah yang raja akan berikan untuk mendengarkan Dharma.

en: Śakra, who wished to test the king’s resolve to hear Dharma, approached him and recited one verse, which the king greatly rejoices in. He then told the king if he wished to hear another he must tend a fire for seven days and at the end throw himself into the fire.

In the middle is a large fire blazing from an altar. The king stands to the right of it, holding a lotus on his hand, which perhaps signifies the transfigured lotus pond which is not otherwise shown. On the left sits the large and fearsome-looking yakṣa, Śakra in disguise. He is waiting for the king to fulfil his promise.
id: Śakra, yang hendak menguji tekad raja untuk mendengarkan Dharma, mendekatinya dan mendaras satu syair, yang membuat raja sangat gembira. Ia kemudian mengatakan kepada raja jika ia ingin mendengar yang lain, ia harus menyalakan api selama tujuh hari dan pada akhirnya menerjunkan dirinya ke dalam api.

Di tengah, api besar berkobar dari altar. Raja berdiri di kanan altar, memegang teratai di tangannya, yang mungkin menandakan perubahan kolam teratai yang tak ditampilkan. Di kiri, duduk yaksa besar dan tampak menyeramkan, Śakra dalam samaran. Ia sedang menunggu raja untuk memenuhi janjinya.

en: The king did as he said he would and threw himself into the fire in order to learn more Dharma, but as he did so it transformed into a lotus pond, and the king was unhurt. Śakra then revealed his true form and spoke the first verse again, which the king caused to be taught throughout the kingdom.

In this scene the king is sat in the middle in a pavilion and on a raised seat. Śakra sits on the right, presumably with two other devas. Both the king and Śakra are marked by halos. It seems to be the moment when Śakra speaks the verse.
id: Raja melakukan apa yang telah ia katakan dan menerjunkan diri ke dalam api demi lebih banyak belajar Dharma, tetapi ketika ia melakukannya, api berubah menjadi kolam teratai, dan raja tak terluka. Śakra kemudian mengungkap wujud aslinya dan mengucapkan syair pertama lagi, yang kemudian raja minta untuk diajarkan di seluruh kerajaan.

Dalam adegan ini, raja duduk di tengah dalam anjungan dan di kursi tinggi. Śakra duduk di kanan, mungkin dengan dua dewa lainnya. Raja dan Śakra ditandai dengan aura kepala. Sepertinya ini saat ketika Śakra mendaraskan syair.

en: Krom identifies the next three reliefs as belonging to the Sambulā (Ja 519) story. But the reliefs hardly support such a reading, and go against the story as we know it.

It is because of panel 62 that Krom identifies the story as being that of Sambulā, but the characters are wrong: we would at least expect to see the yakṣa and the princess together with Śakra, not Airāvata and a man! Similarly the next scene simply doesn’t fit Sambulā’s story at all.
id: Krom mengenali tiga relief berikutnya sebagai cerita Sambulā (Ja 519). Namun relief-relief itu tidak mendukung cerita tersebut, dan bertentangan dengan cerita yang kita tahu.

Ini karena panel 62 yang Krom kenali ceritanya sebagai Sambulā, tetapi tokoh-tokohnya salah: kita setidaknya berharap melihat yaksa dan putri bersama dengan Śakra, bukan Airāvata dan seorang pria! Demikian pula adegan berikutnya tidak pas dengan cerita Sambulā sama sekali.

en: In the centre of the relief sit a king and queen casually on cushions. The building is fairly elaborate, with pillars and decorations. The figure of the king is particularly worn down.

On the left we see an attendant holding a fly whisk and courtiers sitting on the floor, with an elephant, leaf-fan and parasol behind them. On the right are more courtiers, including two guards who hold swords, as they sit under a tree.
id: Di tengah relief, raja dan ratu duduk santai di bantal. Bangunannya cukup rumit, dengan banyak pilar dan hiasan. Sosok raja sangatlah rusak.

Di kiri kita lihat pelayan memegang kebutan dan pegawai duduk di lantai, dengan gajah, kipas daun, dan payung di belakang mereka. Di kanan ada lebih banyak pegawai, termasuk dua pengawal yang memegang pedang, kala mereka duduk di bawah pohon.

en: There are two scenes in this relief: on the right we see the couple living in a wilderness, there are trees, a river with fish, two lions in a den and deer to mark the scene.

On the left we see Śakra, holding the double vajra, standing between his vehicle Airāvata who sits on the far left, and what is probably the male character from the previous scene sitting holding his hands in añjali on the right.
id: Ada dua adegan dalam relief ini: di kanan kita lihat pasangan yang hidup di belantara, ada pepohonan, sungai dengan ikan, dua singa di sarang, dan rusa, untuk menandai adegan.

Di kiri, kita lihat Śakra, memegang petir ganda, berdiri di antara kendaraannya, Airāvata yang duduk di kiri jauh, dan yang mungkin sosok lelaki dari adegan sebelumnya duduk menangkupkan tangannya di kanan.

name.en: 63. A Meeting between a Royal Couple and a Bodhisattva
name.id: 63. Pertemuan Antara Pasangan Kerajaan dan Bodhisattwa

en: In the middle-right we see a large collonaded and decorated building, within which sits the king with his consort on the left and a character marked as a Bodhisattva on the right. The king and the Bodhisattva appear to be in conversation. On the far right two figures crouch in an antechamber.
On the left we see the normal crowd of courtiers sat under a tree, with the usual royal insignia above them. They hold various postures as the action proceeds in the palace.
id: Di kanan tengah, kita melihat bangunan besar dengan tiang dan dihias, di dalamnya duduk raja dengan permaisurinya di kiri dan sosok yang ditandai sebagai Bodhisattwa di kanan. Raja dan Bodhisattwa tampak sedang bicara. Di kanan jauh, dua sosok berjongkok di selasar.
Di kiri kita lihat kerumunan pegawai biasa duduk di bawah pohon, dengan lambang kerajaan seperti biasanya di atas mereka. Mereka menampilkan berbagai postur saat kejadian berlangsung di istana.

background.en: Unlike most of the Avadāna stories, which take place in a past life of the Buddha or one of his disciples, this one is set contemporary with Buddha Gautama’s life. The story is known to us from Divyāvadāna 37, and it is the last tale in that collection, but it is probable the sculptors knew a somewhat different version of the story.
background.id: Tidak seperti kebanyakan cerita Avadana, yang terjadi pada kehidupan lampau Buddha atau salah satu siswa-Nya, yang satu ini terjadi semasa dengan kehidupan Buddha Gautama. Cerita kita ketahui dari Divyāvadāna 37, dan merupakan cerita terakhir dalam kumpulan itu, tetapi mungkin para perupa mengetahui ragam cerita yang agak berbeda.

en: In the time of Lord Buddha king Bimbisāra ruled in Rājagṛha, and in the distant city of Roruka Rudrāyaṇa ruled as king. One time merchants from Rājagṛha visited Roruka, and there followed an exchange of gifts between the kings, the last of which was a portrait of the Buddha, with some of his teachings inscribed on it.

When Rudrāyaṇa heard of the Buddha he was duly impressed, and asked for a monk to be sent to Roruka. The Buddha sent Ven. Mahākātyāyana and 500 monks to the city. Mahākātyāyana’s preaching led to two householders, Tiṣya and Puṣya, attaining Arahatship. Later they passed away and stūpas were built for them.

The king wanted Ven. Mahākātyāyana to preach in his harem, but the monk told him it was not allowable, and that he should ask for a bhikṣuṇī. He did so and the nun Śailā came with 500 other nuns to Roruka. Her teaching impressed the ladies, especially the queen Candrapabhā, and when the queen learned of her impending death she asked to be ordained for the final week of her life.

After passing away she was reborn in heaven and later appeared to the king as a goddess and spoke about the benefits of ordination, at which the king decided to appoint his son Śikhaṇḍī as king, and get himself ordained. The old king appointed two advisors for his son also: Hiru and Bhiru. He then retired to Rājagṛha and was ordained.

King Śikhaṇḍī, although he started off well, soon started to rule unjustly, and the former king decided to return to Roruka to admonish him. Two evil advisors to the king persuaded him to have Ven. Rudrāyaṇa killed on the road. This was done, but not until shortly after he had attained Arahatship.

The king felt remorse for killing his father who was also a Arahat, and the two evil ministers decided to play a trick on him to persuade him that there were no Arahats in the world. They trained some cats and planted them in the stūpas of Tiṣya and Puṣya, and then persuaded the king the Arahats had been reborn as these cats.

The evil ministers also had Ven. Mahākātyāyana attacked by the townsfolk and buried alive under a pile of dirt. Mahākātyāyana, of course, survived, and then predicted the downfall of Roruka and its folk: showers of riches would fall from the sky for six days, but on the seventh everyone would be buried under a sandstorm. The two good ministers, Hiru and Bhiru, were warned in advance of the coming events, and escaped and founded the cities of Hiruka and Bhirukaccha.

Mahākātyāyana also left the city accompanied by Śyāmāka, Hiru’s son, and by the goddess of the city. The latter later became goddess at Khara; and Śyāmāka became king at a city that was subsequently named after him. Mahākātyāyana himself went on to Vokkāṇa. Along the way he left relics at these various cities, before returning to Śrāvastī. The Buddha then told some past life stories to explain the karmic connection.
id: Pada masa Buddha, Raja Bimbisāra memerintah di Rājagṛha, dan jauh di Negeri Roruka, Rudrāyaṇa memerintah sebagai raja. Suatu waktu pedagang dari Rājagṛha mengunjungi Roruka, dan di sana terjadi pertukaran hadiah di antara raja, dan yang terakhir adalah lukisan Buddha, dengan beberapa ajaran-Nya tertera di atasnya.

Ketika Rudrāyaṇa mendengar tentang Buddha, ia sangat terkesan, dan meminta seorang biksu dikirim ke Roruka. Buddha mengirim Yang Mulia Mahākātyāyana dan 500 biksu ke Roruka. Ajaran Mahākātyāyana membimbing dua perumah-tangga, Tiṣya dan Puṣya, mencapai Arahatta. Nantinya mereka meninggal dan stupa dibangun untuk mereka.

Raja ingin Mahākātyāyana mengajar di rumah selirnya, tetapi sang biksu berkata kepadanya bahwa itu tidak dibolehkan, dan raja harus meminta seorang biksuni. Raja melakukannya dan Biksuni Śailā datang bersama 500 biksuni lainnya ke Roruka. Ajarannya mengesankan para perempuan, terutama Ratu Candrapabhā, dan ketika ratu mengetahui ajalnya telah dekat, ia minta ditahbis pada minggu terakhir hidupnya.

Setelah meninggal, ratu terlahir ulang di surga, lalu muncul di hadapan raja sebagai dewi dan bicara tentang manfaat penahbisan, yang membuat raja memutuskan untuk menunjuk putranya, Śikhaṇḍī, sebagai raja, kemudian ia sendiri dinobatkan. Raja tua juga menunjuk dua penasihat untuk putranya: Hiru dan Bhiru. Ia kemudian undur diri ke Rājagṛha dan ditahbis.

Raja Śikhaṇḍī, walau ia mulai dengan baik, tak lama mulai memerintah dengan tidak adil, dan raja terdahulu memutuskan untuk kembali ke Roruka untuk menasihatinya. Dua penasihat jahat raja membujuknya untuk membunuh Yang Mulia Rudrāyaṇa di perjalanan. Itu dilakukan, namun tak lama setelah ia mencapai Arahatta.

Raja merasa sangat menyesal telah membunuh ayahnya yang juga seorang Arahanta, namun dua menteri jahat memutuskan untuk mengelabuinya dengan meyakinkannya bahwa tidak ada Arahanta di dunia. Mereka melatih dua kucing dan menaruh mereka di stupa Tiṣya dan Puṣya, lalu meyakinkan raja bahwa para Arahanta terlahir ulang menjadi kucing-kucing itu.

Para menteri jahat juga membuat Mahākātyāyana diserang oleh warga kota dan dikubur hidup-hidup di bawah gundukan tanah. Mahākātyāyana, tentu saja, selamat, lalu meramalkan keruntuhan Roruka dan rakyatnya: hujan kekayaan akan tercurah dari langit selama enam hari, tetapi pada hari ketujuh semua orang akan terkubur di bawah badai pasir. Dua menteri baik, Hiru dan Bhiru, diperingatkan sebelum bencana terjadi, lalu meloloskan diri dan mendirikan kota Hiruka dan Bhirukaccha.

Mahākātyāyana juga meninggalkan kota ditemani Śyāmāka, putra Hiru, dan dengan dewi penjaga kota. Dewi itu lalu menjadi dewi di Khara; dan Śyāmāka menjadi raja di kota yang dinamai sesuai namanya. Mahākātyāyana sendiri pergi ke Vokkāṇa. Di sepanjang jalan ia meninggalkan relik di berbagai kota ini, sebelum kembali ke Śrāvastī. Buddha kemudian menceritakan beberapa cerita kehidupan lampau untuk menjelaskan keterkaitan karma.

en: Some merchants from Rājagṛha undertook a long journey and eventually came to Roruka, where king Rudrāyaṇa ruled. Upon meeting them, the king asked if they knew of any king as great as he himself was, and they described the virtues of king Bimbisāra of Rājagṛha.

King Rudrāyaṇa is seen sitting in his court with his consort behind him. In front of him sit three merchants, the one at the front holds his hands in añjali. It is hard to tell whether the three on the far right are also merchants, or courtiers. Outside we see a group has gathered and are receiving gifts.
id: Beberapa pedagang dari Rājagṛha melakukan perjalanan panjang dan akhirnya tiba di Roruka, tempat Raja Rudrāyaṇa memerintah. Setelah menemui mereka, raja bertanya apakah mereka tahu ada raja yang seagung dirinya, dan mereka menggambarkan kebajikan Raja Bimbisāra dari Rājagṛha.

Raja Rudrāyaṇa terlihat duduk di istananya dengan permaisuri di belakangnya. Di depannya duduk tiga pedagang, orang di depan menangkupkan tangan. Sulit untuk mengatakan apakah tiga orang di kanan jauh juga pedagang, atau pegawai. Di luar kita melihat rombongan berkumpul dan menerima hadiah.

en: In Divyāvadāna King Rudrāyaṇa sent a letter and a box of jewels, but these are shown separately in the panels, so it looks like a slightly different text was known to the sculptors. From the panels it seems that Rudrāyaṇa first sent a letter, which the merchants duly presented to king Bimbisāra when they returned.

The panel shows king Bimbisāra sitting with two of his consorts on a decorated podium. He has his hand stretched out and appears as though speaking. In front of him sit an entourage, who have returned from Roruka with a letter, which the foremost of the merchants holds in his hands.
id: Dalam Divyāvadāna, Raja Rudrāyaṇa mengirim surat dan sekotak perhiasan, tetapi ini ditampilkan terpisah dalam panel, sehingga sepertinya naskah yang diketahui para perupa sedikit berbeda. Dalam panel tampak Rudrāyaṇa yang pertama mengirim surat, yang para pedagang sampaikan kepada Raja Bimbisāra ketika mereka kembali.

Panel memperlihatkan Raja Bimbisāra duduk dengan dua pendampingnya di mimbar yang dihias. Ia mengulurkan tangannya dan tampak bicara. Di depannya duduk rombongan, yang telah kembali dari Roruka dengan sepucuk surat, yang dipegang oleh pedagang terdepan di tangannya.

en: It doesn’t appear anywhere in the Divyāvadāna story that a banquet was sent to King Rudrāyaṇa, and it is hardly feasible either, so I think Krom’s identification must be faulty here. We do see dishes full of what are possibly grains, so maybe some sort of tribute was sent.

The king and queen sit on the right of a long pavilion. Before them are many dishes and a large pot, possibly of rice or some other staple. On the left others, sitting and standing under a tree, come with gifts, one holding a bowl, another a pot.
id: Tidak muncul di mana pun dalam cerita Divyāvadāna bahwa jamuan makan dikirim ke Raja Rudrāyaṇa, dan sulit dimungkinkan juga, jadi saya rasa pengenalan Krom pasti salah di sini. Kita memang melihat hidangan lengkap dengan apa yang mungkin bebijian, jadi mungkin semacam persembahan yang dikirim.

Raja dan ratu duduk di kanan anjungan panjang. Di depan mereka banyak hidangan dan periuk besar, mungkin nasi atau makanan pokok lainnya. Di kiri, yang lain duduk dan berdiri di bawah pohon datang dengan persembahan, yang satu pegang mangkuk, yang lain periuk.

en: If we are reconstructing the story successfully then the second time the merchants returned to Rājagṛha they brought a gift of jewels for the king, and so begins the exchange of gifts between the two kings.

The king and queen sit in a pavilion on the far right. In front of them sit five nobles. The foremost is worshipping the king, and the hindmost is taking possession of the box of jewels from the merchants. Behind the merchants sit others under the trees.
id: Jika kita berhasil menyusun kembali cerita ini, maka ini kedua kalinya para pedagang kembali ke Rājagṛha membawa hadiah permata untuk raja, jadi dimulailah pertukaran hadiah di antara kedua raja.

Raja dan ratu duduk di anjungan di kanan jauh. Di depan mereka duduk lima bangsawan. Yang paling depan menyembah raja, dan yang paling belakang mengambil kotak permata dari para pedagang. Di belakang pedagang duduk yang lain di bawah pohon.

en: King Bimbisāra asked the merchants what Rudrāyaṇa might lack, and was told the king had plenty of jewellery, but lacked the fine clothes they had in Rājagṛha, so Bimbisāra sent a set of fine clothes to his friend.

King Rudrāyaṇa sits with his consort inside a decorated pavilion. Three of the merchants sit on the floor in front of him. Behind them are two who are standing, one of them holding a chest, presumably containing the clothes that have been sent.
id: Raja Bimbisāra bertanya kepada para pedagang apa yang Rudrāyaṇa mungkin belum punyai, lalu diberi tahu bahwa raja punya banyak perhiasan, tetapi kekurangan pakaian indah yang mereka punya di Rājagṛha, sehingga Bimbisāra mengirim seperangkat pakaian indah untuk temannya.

Raja Rudrāyaṇa duduk dengan permaisurinya dalam anjungan yang dihias. Tiga pedagang duduk di lantai di depannya. Di belakang mereka ada dua yang berdiri, salah satunya pegang peti, mungkin berisi kiriman pakaian.

en: The next gift king Rudrāyaṇa sent was a jewelled cuirass that had various protective qualities. King Bimbisāra asked his experts to assess the worth, but they found each of the jewels on it to be priceless.

King Bimbisāra sits with his consorts on the right. Five nobles sit directly in front of him, and there are merchants sitting under the trees behind who pass the body armour to the nobles for the king.
id: Hadiah berikutnya yang dikirim Raja Rudrāyaṇa adalah zirah berhias permata yang punya berbagai guna perlindungan. Raja Bimbisāra minta para ahlinya untuk menilai harganya, namun mereka menemukan tiap permata yang disematkan tak ternilai harganya.

Raja Bimbisāra duduk dengan permaisurinya di kanan. Lima bangsawan duduk tepat di depannya, dan ada para pedagang duduk di bawah pepohonan di belakang yang menyerahkan zirah tubuh kepada para bangsawan untuk raja.

name.en: 70. The King sends a Portrait of the Buddha

en: King Bimbisāra not knowing how to reply to such a precious gift decided to consult the Buddha about the matter, and the Buddha told him to have a portrait of himself made, to add three teachings of the Dharma, and to send that, which the king duly did.

The panel shows the procession as it enters into the city, which was a grand affair. In the centre we see a merchant sitting atop an elephant and holding the portrait, which is rolled up, and on his lap. In front go the nobles who have come out to meet him, though the king does not appear to have been portrayed.
id: Raja Bimbisāra tidak tahu bagaimana membalas hadiah yang begitu berharga memutuskan untuk bertanya kepada Buddha tentang masalah ini, dan Buddha memberitahunya untuk membuat lukisan diri-Nya, menambahkan tiga ajaran Dharma, dan mengirim itu, yang raja lakukan dengan baik.

Panel menunjukkan iringan ketika memasuki kota, yang merupakan peristiwa besar. Di tengah, kita lihat pedagang duduk di atas gajah dan memegang lukisan, yang digulung, di pangkuannya. Di depan ada para bangsawan yang keluar untuk menyambutnya, walau raja tampak tidak digambarkan.

name.en: 71. The King sends for a Monk

en: King Rudrāyaṇa, after being impressed by the portrait, examined the three Dharma teachings on it very carefully, and by the end of the night he had attained stream-entry. He then called the merchants and requested that they return and ask for a monk to be sent to Roruka.

King Rudrāyaṇa sits in his pavilion with two of his consorts, before him are a group of people, presumably the merchants, though they look more like nobles. In Divyāvadāna, however, there is no meeting with nobles on this occasion, so we must presume that these are the merchants.
id: Raja Rudrāyaṇa, setelah terpesona oleh lukisan itu, mempelajari tiga ajaran Dharma di lukisan itu dengan sangat saksama, dan pada akhir malam ia mencapai Pemasuk-Arus. Ia lalu memanggil para pedagang dan minta agar mereka kembali dan memohon satu biksu dikirim ke Roruka.

Raja Rudrāyaṇa duduk di anjungan bersama dua selirnya, di depannya ada sekelompok orang, mungkin para pedagang, walau mereka lebih mirip bangsawan. Akan tetapi, dalam Divyāvadāna, tidak ada pertemuan dengan para bangsawan pada kejadian ini, jadi kita harus menganggap bahwa ini adalah para pedagang.

en: The merchants returned to king Bimbisāra, and the king requested the Buddha to send a monk to his friend. The Buddha, knowing the right monk for the mission, sent Ven. Mahākātyāyana. After being received, the venerable taught for the king and his subjects, with great success.

There is a long pavilion on the right in which sit the king and Ven. Mahākātyāyana, the latter on a dais that is raised above the king. On the left are nobles and merchants sitting, who will themselves understand Dharma and attain success.
id: Para pedagang kembali ke Raja Bimbisāra, dan raja meminta Buddha untuk mengirim satu biksu kepada temannya. Buddha, mengetahui biksu yang tepat untuk misi itu, mengutus Yang Mulia Mahākātyāyana. Setelah disambut, beliau mengajar raja dan rakyatnya, dengan keberhasilan besar.

Ada anjungan panjang di kanan yang di dalamnya duduk raja dan Mahākātyāyana, yang duduk di mimbar yang ditinggikan di atas raja. Di kiri duduk para bangsawan dan pedagang, yang mereka sendiri akan memahami Dharma dan mencapai keberhasilan.

en: Queen Candraprabhā and the ladies of the court wanted to hear the teachings for themselves, and Ven. Mahākātyāyana advised that the king to request a nun be sent. When the Buddha heard of this he decided to sent the Arahat Bhikṣuṇī Śailā and her followers.

The king, the queen and her ladies-in-waiting sit in a long pavilion. The king himself holds out his hands in añjali. In front of him sits the Arahat nun Śailā, and behind him are four of his consorts, which one is supposed to be Candraprabhā is not made clear. On the right one person appears to be guarding the building.
id: Ratu Candraprabhā dan para dayang di istana ingin mendengarkan ajaran untuk mereka, dan Mahākātyāyana menyarankan agar raja meminta dikirim biksuni. Ketika Buddha mendengar ini, Ia memutuskan untuk mengirim Arahanta Biksuni Śailā dan para pengikutnya.

Raja, ratu, dan para dayang duduk di anjungan panjang. Raja sendiri menangkupkan tangan. Di depannya duduk Arahanta Biksuni Śailā, dan di belakang raja ada empat pendampingnya, yang mana seharusnya Candraprabhā tidaklah jelas. Di kanan, satu orang tampak menjaga gedung.

en: The king used to play the vīna and queen Candraprabhā would dance for him. One day the king noticed that she was destined to die within the week. When the queen understood she was dying she requested to be allowed to ordain, and the king granted her request provided she agreed to come back to him if reborn amongst the gods.

Two nuns sit on a raised platform in a long pavilion that takes up the whole panel. In front of them is the queen, now bereft of her finery, which is being held by the lady behind her. I don’t think this is meant to show the actual ordination, which would require more nuns, and separation from the laity. Rather it is the request for ordination that is shown here.
id: Raja biasa memainkan kecapi dan Ratu Candraprabhā akan menari untuknya. Suatu hari raja mengetahui bahwa ratu tergariskan akan mati dalam seminggu. Ketika ratu tahu bahwa ia jelang ajal, ia mohon dibolehkan untuk ditahbis, dan raja mengabulkan permohonannya asalkan ia setuju untuk kembali kepadanya jika terlahir ulang di antara para dewa.

Dua biksuni duduk di mimbar tinggi di anjungan panjang yang memenuhi seluruh panel. Di depan mereka adalah ratu, kini menanggalkan perhiasannya, yang dipegang oleh perempuan di belakangnya. Saya rasa ini tidak dimaksudkan untuk menunjukkan penahbisan yang sebenarnya, yang membutuhkan lebih banyak biksuni, dan terpisah dari perumah-tangga. Alih-alih, yang ditampilkan di sini adalah permohonan penahbisan.

name.en: 75. The Goddess appears to the King

en: After passing away the queen was reborn amongst the gods. Desiring to see the Buddha she appeared before him in Rājagṛha and, after listening to the teachings, attained stream-entry. She then remembered she had promised to speak to her former lord. The king, awakened from sleep by her, wanted to make love, and she told him she had been reborn as a goddess owing to her ordination, and he must be reborn in the same heaven if he wanted to make love to her again.

The scene on the relief differs from the text: here the king and the goddess meet together in a chamber, but it does not appear to be a bedroom. Also, outside all his attendants and the nobility are awake and apparently witnesses to what takes place. They are probably included to fill up the space on the relief.
id: Setelah meninggal, ratu terlahir ulang di antara para dewa. Ingin melihat Buddha, ia muncul di hadapan Buddha di Rājagṛha, lalu setelah mendengarkan ajaran, mencapai Pemasuk-Arus. Ratu lalu ingat bahwa ia telah berjanji untuk bicara dengan mantan rajanya. Raja, dibangunkan dari tidur oleh ratu, ingin bercinta, dan ratu mengatakan kepada raja bahwa ia telah terlahir ulang sebagai dewi berkat penahbisannya, dan raja harus terlahir ulang di surga yang sama jika ia ingin bercinta lagi dengannya.

Adegan relief berbeda dengan naskah: di sini raja dan dewi bertemu di suatu ruangan, tetapi tampaknya bukan kamar tidur. Juga, di luar, semua pelayannya dan bangsawan terjaga dan tampak menyaksikan apa yang terjadi. Mereka mungkin disertakan untuk mengisi ruang dalam relief.

name.en: 76. The King meets with his Son

en: The king, being admonished by a goddess thus, decided to pass the kingdom to the charge of his son and to go forth himself. He first advised his son to listen to the ministers Hiru and Bhiru as he would to the old king himself. He then departed for Rājagṛha with a single attendant.

In the middle is a large pavilion with the king and prince Śikhaṇḍī sat inside discussing the king’s decision. On either side are signs of the king’s power: his soldiers with bows, swords and an unsaddled elephant.
id: Raja, dinasihati oleh dewi, lantas memutuskan untuk menyerahkan kerajaan ke tangan putranya dan ia sendiri menjadi biksu. Pertama ia menasihati putranya untuk mendengarkan menteri Hiru dan Bhiru seperti yang ia lakukan terhadap raja tua sendiri. Raja kemudian pergi ke Rājagṛha dengan satu pelayan.

Di tengah ada anjungan besar dengan raja dan Pangeran Śikhaṇḍī duduk di dalam membahas keputusan raja. Di kedua sisi ada tanda kekuasaan raja: para prajuritnya dengan busur, pedang, dan gajah tak berpelana.

en: When Rudrāyaṇa arrived in Rājagṛha, king Bimbisāra took him to the Buddha, where he was duly ordained. Later when the monk Rudrāyaṇa entered the city for alms he had an interview with Bimbisāra in which he laid out the reasons he had gone forth.

On the right we see signs of some of the nobility that followed king Bimbisāra when he went to speak to the newly ordained monk. The king himself and the bhikṣu Rudrāyaṇa sit in a conventional pavilion, the monk, with simple robes and shaven head, sits higher than the king.
id: Ketika Rudrāyaṇa tiba di Rājagṛha, Raja Bimbisāra membawanya kepada Buddha, di mana ia ditahbis dengan layak. Kemudian ketika Biksu Rudrāyaṇa memasuki kota untuk menerima derma, ia bertanya-jawab dengan Bimbisāra, yang mana ia membeberkan alasannya menjadi biksu.

Di kanan, kita lihat tanda beberapa bangsawan yang mengikuti Raja Bimbisāra ketika ia pergi untuk bicara dengan biksu yang baru ditahbis. Raja sendiri dan Biksu Rudrāyaṇa duduk di anjungan bersahaja; biksu, dengan jubah sederhana dan kepala dicukur, duduk lebih tinggi daripada raja.

name.en: 78. Śikhaṇḍī agrees to kill his Father

en: After a while a merchant arrived from Roruka and Ven. Rudrāyaṇa asked how his former kingdom was faring. He was told the king was now corrupt, and so he decided to go and help get him back on course. When Śikhaṇḍī heard his father was returning, fearing the loss of his kingdom, he agreed to having him killed.

The panel is divided into sections. On the right we see Rudrāyaṇa sitting under trees and talking with the merchant; in the middle we see Śikhaṇḍī talking with his evil ministers who persuade him to have his father assassinated; on the far left someone is informing what is probably the king’s mother of the events.
id: Setelah beberapa lama, seorang pedagang tiba dari Roruka dan Yang Mulia Rudrāyaṇa bertanya bagaimana nasib kerajaannya. Ia dikabari bahwa raja sekarang korup, sehingga Rudrāyaṇa memutuskan untuk pergi dan membantu putranya kembali ke jalur yang benar. Ketika Śikhaṇḍī mendengar ayahnya akan kembali, takut kehilangan kerajaannya, ia setuju untuk membunuhnya.

Panel dibagi menjadi beberapa bagian. Di kanan kita lihat Rudrāyaṇa duduk di bawah pohon dan bicara dengan pedagang; di tengah kita lihat Śikhaṇḍī bicara dengan para menterinya yang jahat yang membujuknya agar ayahnya dibunuh; di kiri jauh seseorang memberi tahu apa yang terjadi kepada yang mungkin ibunda raja.

name.en: 79. The King hears of his Father’s Death

en: While Ven. Rudrāyaṇa was on his way to Roruka he first attained Arahatship and then was killed by the assassins. When king Śikhaṇḍī heard he felt remorse, and went to see his mother, who assured him the old king was not his father, and so he had not committed that crime.

Again the panel is divided. On the right we see the king meeting with the two evil ministers who had counselled him badly, and the assassins still carrying their weapons; on the left we see the king meeting with his mother who assures him the old king was not his father after all.
id: Ketika Yang Mulia Rudrāyaṇa dalam perjalanannya ke Roruka, ia terlebih dahulu mencapai Arahatta, barulah dibunuh oleh para pembunuh. Ketika Raja Śikhaṇḍī mendengar itu, ia merasa menyesal, lalu pergi menemui ibunya, yang meyakinkannya bahwa raja tua itu bukan ayahnya, sehingga ia tidak melakukan kejahatan itu.

Lagi, panel dibagi. Di kanan kita lihat raja bertemu dengan dua menteri jahat yang telah menasihatinya dengan buruk, dan para pembunuh masih membawa senjata mereka; di kiri kita lihat raja bertemu dengan ibunya yang meyakinkannya bahwa raja tua itu sama sekali bukanlah ayahnya.

en: In order now to persuade king Śikhaṇḍī that there were no Arahats in the world an elaborate trick was set up at the stūpas of the kingdom’s most famous Arahats, Tiṣya and Puṣya. Two cats were trained to answer to the Arahats previous names and to walk round the stūpas when called, as though they had been reborn in feline form.

On the right sits the king and the queen mother. On the left we see the lovely stūpas of the Arahats. While below them are the trained cats. To the left of them are the two evil ministers who have set up the trick. Notice the parasols (chatra) set up over the stūpas, which is still done today.
id: Untuk meyakinkan Raja Śikhaṇḍī bahwa tidak ada Arahanta di dunia, suatu tipuan terperinci direncanakan di stupa Arahanta kerajaan yang paling terkenal, Tiṣya dan Puṣya. Dua kucing dilatih untuk menyahut nama Arahanta sebelumnya dan berjalan mengelilingi stupa ketika dipanggil, seolah mereka telah terlahir ulang dalam raga kucing.

Di kanan, duduk raja dan ibu ratu. Di kiri, kita lihat stupa indah para Arahanta. Sementara di bawah mereka ada dua kucing terlatih. Di kiri mereka ada dua menteri jahat yang mengatur tipuannya. Perhatikan payung (chatra) dipasang di atas stupa, yang masih dilakukan sampai sekarang.

en: After being convinced there were no Arahats in the world, king Śikhaṇḍī stopped supporting the monks and nuns, and they all left, except Vens. Mahākātyāyana and Śailā. One day the king, feeling slighted, ordered his people to throw dirt over the monk. The venerable was buried but survived and uttered a prophecy about the result of that action.

There are two scenes again. On the right the king is traveling around the city in a palaquin with the normal marks of royalty: parasol, peacock-feather fan and standards. On the left Ven. Mahākātyāyana utters the prophecy about the destruction of the city in the presence of Hiru and Bhiru, the good ministers. One other person is present, perhaps it is Hiru’s son, Śyāmāka.
id: Setelah diyakinkan bahwa tidak ada Arahanta di dunia, Raja Śikhaṇḍī berhenti mendukung para biksu dan biksuni, sehingga mereka semua pergi, kecuali Yang Mulia Mahākātyāyana dan Śailā. Suatu hari, raja, merasa diremehkan, memerintah rakyatnya untuk menimbun biksu itu dengan tanah. Biksu itu terkubur, tetapi selamat dan menyatakan ramalan mengenai akibat perbuatan itu.

Ada dua adegan lagi. Di kanan, raja berkeliling kota di atas tandu dengan lambang kerajaan seperti biasa: payung, kipas bulu merak, dan panji. Di kiri, Mahākātyāyana menyatakan ramalan tentang kehancuran kota di hadapan Hiru dan Bhiru, para menteri yang baik. Satu orang lain hadir, mungkin itu putra Hiru, Śyāmāka.

en: The prophecy was that on six successive days riches would pour down on the city, but on the seventh all the people who had attacked him would enter it and it would be buried under dirt. He advised the good ministers to collect the rain of diamonds on the sixth day and make their escape by boat.

On the far right the building symbolises the city, and right next to it the king and his queen sit inside a pavilion. On the left riches are pouring down from the sky and the people are collecting them. I think we must take it that the two in the middle left are Hiru and Bhiru loading up their boat before their escape.
id: Ramalannya adalah dalam enam hari berturut-turut kekayaan akan tercurah ke kota, tetapi pada hari ketujuh semua orang yang menyerangnya akan masuk dan terkubur di bawah tanah. Ia menganjurkan para menteri yang baik untuk mengumpulkan hujan berlian pada hari keenam dan meloloskan diri dengan perahu.

Di kanan jauh, bangunan melambangkan kota, dan tepat di sebelahnya raja dan ibu ratu duduk dalam anjungan. Di kiri kekayaan mengalir turun dari langit dan rakyat mengumpulkannya. Saya rasa kita harus menduga bahwa dua orang di kiri tengah adalah Hiru dan Bhiru yang memuati perahu mereka sebelum menyelamatkan diri.

name.en: 83. The Stūpa over the Brass Bowl

en: On the seventh day the city was destroyed, but the city devatā escaped along with Ven. Mahākātyāyana and Śyāmāka. They went to Khara and the devatā agreed to take up residence there. Ven. Mahākātyāyana gave his brass bowl as a relic, and they built a stūpa over it and initiated a festival.

In the centre we see the stūpa that has been built over the brass bowl Ven. Mahākātyāyana left behind. Left of the stūpa is the devatā who is honouring it with a light, and behind her are her attendants with gifts. On the far left are the musicians celebrating the festival.
id: Pada hari ketujuh, kota hancur, tetapi dewata kota pergi bersama Mahākātyāyana dan Śyāmāka. Mereka pergi ke Khara dan dewata setuju untuk tinggal di sana. Mahākātyāyana memberikan mangkuk kuningannya sebagai relik, dan mereka membangun stupa di atasnya dan mengadakan perayaan.

Di tengah, kita lihat stupa yang dibangun di atas mangkuk kuningan yang Mahākātyāyana tinggalkan. Di kiri stupa ada dewata yang menghormatinya dengan cahaya, dan di belakangnya ada para pelayannya membawa persembahan. Di kiri jauh ada para pemusik yang meramaikan perayaan.

en: After leaving Khara with Śyāmāka Ven. Mahākātyāyana traveled on to a nearby town. He left his attendant outside and went into town for alms. Now the people of that town were looking for someone to make king. Śyāmāka had fallen asleep under a tree, but its shadow never left him, so they took this as a sign and requested him to stay on as king.

On the right is a building signifying the town, and in front of it must be Śyāmāka. In front of him are people on their knees obviously making the request that he stay on as their king. A character on the far left is leaving, perhaps it is meant to be Ven. Mahākātyāyana leaving the city.
id: Setelah meninggalkan Khara dengan Śyāmāka, Mahākātyāyana melakukan perjalanan ke kota terdekat. Ia meninggalkan pelayannya di luar dan pergi ke kota untuk menerima derma makanan. Sekarang rakyat di kota itu mencari seseorang untuk jadi raja. Śyāmāka tertidur di bawah pohon, tetapi bayangannya tak pernah meninggalkannya, jadi rakyat menganggap ini sebagai pertanda dan memintanya untuk tinggal sebagai raja.

Di kanan ada bangunan yang menandakan kota, dan di depannya pasti Śyāmāka. Di depannya ada rakyat yang berlutut yang jelas memohonnya tinggal sebagai raja mereka. Satu sosok di ujung kiri akan pergi, mungkin ia Mahākātyāyana yang meninggalkan kota.

en: Ven. Mahākātyāyana next traveled to Vokkāṇa, where his mother was living. He taught Dharma to her and she attained stream-entry. She then requested that her son leave a relic, and he left his staff. Over this staff-relic a stūpa was built.

As in 83 we see the stūpa at the centre of the relief and people gathered all round. Unexpectedly, we do not see Ven. Mahākātyāyana’s mother who asked for the relic. On the right a brahmin stands with a lotus in his hands, and on the left a king offers lights to the stūpa.
id: Mahākātyāyana lalu pergi ke Vokkāṇa, tempat ibunya tinggal. Ia mengajarkan Dharma kepada ibunya, dan ibunya mencapai Pemasuk-Arus. Ia lalu minta putranya meninggalkan relik, dan Mahākātyāyana meninggalkan tongkatnya. Di atas relik tongkat ini, stupa dibangun.

Seperti di relief 83, kita lihat stupa di tengah relief dan orang berkumpul mengelilinginya. Tak dinyana, kita tidak melihat ibunda Mahākātyāyana yang meminta relik tersebut. Di kanan, brahmana berdiri dengan teratai di tangan, dan di kiri raja mempersembahkan pelita ke stupa.

en: The next three panels are assigned by Foucher and Krom to the Rudrāyaṇa story, but on the flimsiest of evidence. In that story it is mentioned in one sentence that after the fall of diamonds in Roruka, the good ministers Hiru and Bhiru sailed away and founded eponymous cities.

86 and 88 are taken as illustrating these events, although they occur in the story a very long time before the end. They also occur simultaneously, and do not interrupt the return of Ven. Mahākātyāyana to Rājagṛha, which supposedly 87 illustrates.
I do not see anything compelling to take the reliefs as illustrating these events, and indeed they seem to be showing another story, unrelated to the Rudrāyaṇa story, and I treat them as such.
id: Tiga panel berikutnya ditetapkan Foucher dan Krom sebagai cerita Rudrāyaṇa, tetapi dengan bukti yang sangat tipis. Dalam cerita disebutkan dalam satu kalimat bahwa setelah hujan berlian di Roruka, para menteri yang baik, Hiru dan Bhiru berlayar pergi dan mendirikan kota yang dinamai pendirinya.

Panel 86 dan 88 dianggap sebagai menggambarkan peristiwa-peristiwa ini, walau mereka muncul dalam cerita, sangat lama sebelum akhir. Mereka juga terjadi serentak, dan tidak menyela kembalinya Mahākātyāyana ke Rājagṛha, yang seharusnya panel 87 gambarkan.

Saya tidak melihat sesuatu yang menarik untuk menetapkan relief sebagai penggambaran peristiwa ini, dan memang mereka tampaknya menampilkan cerita lain, tidak terkait dengan cerita Rudrāyaṇa, dan saya memperlakukannya seperti itu.

en: The relief in divided into two scenes. On the left we see a very detailed picture of a ship on the high seas, with the sails taking full wind and a great deal of movement. The sea itself looks quite choppy, and even the clouds are bent by the wind.

On the left we see some people being greeted by a king and his queen. The people, in plain clothes, are kneeling and standing, and have their hands out as though receiving something from the royal pair. On the far left we see an ordinary house, with servants’ quarters below, and raised roof above. None of these details are mentioned in Hiru’s story.
id: Relief dibagi menjadi dua adegan. Di kiri kita lihat gambar kapal yang sangat rinci di laut lepas, dengan layar diembus angin kencang dan banyak pergerakan. Laut terlihat cukup berombak, bahkan awan bengkok ditiup angin.

Di kiri kita lihat beberapa orang disambut oleh raja dan ratunya. Rakyat, dengan pakaian biasa, berlutut dan berdiri, mengulurkan tangan seolah menerima sesuatu dari pasangan kerajaan. Di kiri jauh kita lihat rumah biasa, dengan asrama pelayan di bawah, dan atap yang dinaikkan di atasnya. Tak satu pun dari rincian ini disebutkan dalam cerita Hiru.

en: Taken as being Mahākātyāyana’s return to Rājagṛha by Foucher, it omits the monks who welcomed him home, and adds characters that play no part in the story. On the right we see what is perhaps a king, holding a lotus, and a queen, holding a bowl. They are surrounded by attendants but do not seem to pay much attention to the monk, who is inside a palisade.

On the left the monk is walking towards a stūpa-topped building, which is probably a temple, the illustration of which fills about a third of the relief. The monk seems to be carrying an indistinct object, and around the compound he is in is a palisade with a gateway.
id: Dianggap sebagai kembalinya Mahākātyāyana ke Rājagṛha oleh Foucher, ini menghapus para biksu yang menyambutnya pulang, dan menambahkan sosok yang tidak berperan dalam cerita. Di kanan kita lihat apa yang mungkin raja, pegang teratai, dan ratu, pegang mangkuk. Mereka dikelilingi para pelayan, tetapi tampak tidak terlalu memerhatikan biksu, yang ada di dalam pagar.

Di kiri biksu berjalan menuju bangunan beratap stupa, yang mungkin kuil, pahatan yang mengisi sekitar sepertiga relief. Biksu tampak membawa benda yang tak jelas, dan di sekitar bangunan tempat ia di dalamnya, dikelilingi pagar dengan pintu gerbang.

en: Again we have a well-drawn ship on the right. In this case the sailors are drawing in the sails and the sea looks less turbulent. One man seems to be riding the rudder at the back of the ship.

On shore we see five characters are sitting under trees, and seemingly have brought a gift which they are presenting to the sage on the far left who sits in his own pavilion. Needless to say, nothing like this is mentioned in the Divyāvadāna story.
id: Sekali lagi kita punya kapal yang dipahat bagus di kanan. Dalam relief ini pelaut menarik layar dan laut terlihat tak terlalu bergejolak. Satu orang tampak mengendalikan kemudi di belakang kapal.

Di pantai kita lihat lima sosok duduk di bawah pohon, dan sepertinya membawa persembahan yang mereka berikan kepada resi di ujung kiri yang duduk di anjungannya. Tak perlu dikatakan, tidak ada yang disebutkan seperti ini dalam cerita Divyāvadāna.

en: The story appears to illustrate a story like the Bhallāṭiya Jātaka in the Pāḷi collection (Ja 504). King Bhallāṭiya, the Bodhisattva in a previous life, one time went out on a hunt with his men and dogs and spent a long time on the hunt. Hearing the pitiful wailing of two kinnaras he bid his dogs hide themselves away, and approached very quietly.

He asked them why they were crying and they explained that one time they had been separated from each other for a night, and they still grieved for that unfortunate event, which had happened nearly 600 years previously. The king learned his lesson and returned to Benares where he was henceforth content to dwell.

I am not entirely convinced that this is the story illustrated as nothing about them suggests the kinnaras are weeping—surely the crucial point of the story—and in fact they look quite content. There was quiet possibly another story involving two kinnaras which we do not know now.
id: Cerita ini muncul untuk menggambarkan cerita Bhallāṭiya Jātaka dalam kumpulan Pāḷi (Ja 504). Raja Bhallāṭiya, Bodhisattwa dalam kehidupan lampau, suatu hari pergi berburu dengan orang-orangnya dan anjinganjingnya, dan menghabiskan waktu lama dalam perburuan. Mendengar ratapan pilu dua kinnara, raja mendiamkan dan menyembunyikan anjinganjingnya, dan mendekat dengan sangat senyap.

Ia bertanya kepada mereka mengapa mereka menangis dan mereka menjelaskan bahwa suatu kali mereka berpisah satu sama lain selama semalam, dan mereka masih berduka atas peristiwa malang itu, yang terjadi hampir 600 tahun yang lalu. Raja mendapat pelajarannya dan kembali ke Benares, di mana ia selanjutnya tinggal dengan merasa cukup.

Saya tidak sepenuhnya yakin bahwa ini cerita yang digambarkan, karena tidak ada satu pun relief yang menunjukkan para kinnara yang menangis— yang pasti hal terpenting dalam cerita—dan pada kenyataannya mereka terlihat cukup puas. Mungkin ada cerita lain yang melibatkan dua kinnara yang saat ini tidak kita ketahui.

en: The scene is set in the wilderness which the trees, the stylised rocks and the flowing river all show. On the right we see the king who is standing, and a couple of his men who sit to the side. The figures are unfortunately damaged.

On the left are pictured the pair of kinnaras. Interestingly, although they are described as human-like in the Jātaka, and their brethren were portrayed as human-like in Sudhana’s story at the beginning of this wall, the kinnaras here are definitely half bird and half human.
id: Adegan terletak di belantara, yang mana pepohonan, bebatuan kasar, dan sungai mengalir, semua ditampilkan. Di kanan, kita lihat raja berdiri, dan sepasang anak buahnya duduk di sampingnya. Sosok-sosok itu sayangnya rusak.

Di kiri terlihat sepasang kinnara. Menariknya, walau mereka digambarkan seperti manusia di Jātaka, dan kerabat mereka digambarkan serupa manusia dalam cerita Sudhana di awal dinding ini, para kinnara di sini jelas setengah burung setengah manusia.

en: In the centre sits the king, this time he has his hands held in añjali, worshipping the semi-divine beings in front of him. Behind him are some of his men, and curiously small portraits of elephants and crocodiles.
On the left the kinnaras stand and the male has his hand held out in front of him as though admonishing the king. Notice the birds in the trees who seem to fly in to witness the scene.
id: Di tengah, duduk raja, kali ini ia menangkupkan tangan, menyembah makhluk setengah-surgawi di depannya. Di belakangnya ada beberapa anak buahnya, dan pahatan kecil gajah dan buaya yang aneh.
Di kiri, berdiri dua kinnara dan yang lelaki menjulurkan tangannya ke depan seolah menegur raja. Perhatikan burung di pohon yang terlihat terbang menyaksikan adegan.

en: Krom assigns this panel to the Bhallāṭiya story, but it seems highly unlikely it is connected, as it is separated by a stairwell from the previous panels, and seems to feature the same characters as on the next panel.

On the right we see a building, and in front of it is a pavilion on which sits a king with his consorts. Many servants seem to be quite squashed under his seat. In front of him is a female attendant with a fly whisk, and then a male figure who sits with his companions and worships the king. Behind the seated figures we see an elephant and horses, so we may take it the visitors are royalty.
id: Krom menetapkan panel ini sebagai cerita Bhallāṭiya, namun sepertinya sangat tidak mungkin berkaitan, karena panel dipisahkan oleh tangga dari panel sebelumnya, dan tampak menampilkan sosok-sosok yang sama seperti pada panel berikutnya.

Di kanan, kita lihat bangunan, dan di depannya ada anjungan yang di dalamnya duduk raja dengan para selirnya. Banyak pelayan tampak cukup tergencet di bawah kursinya. Di depannya ada pelayan wanita dengan kebutan, kemudian sosok lelaki yang duduk dengan teman-temannya memuja raja. Di belakang sosok yang duduk, kita lihat gajah dan kuda, jadi kita dapat menganggap para pengunjung adalah bangsawan.

en: We have another of these scenes which are seen so frequently on the walls at Borobudur: a king or other member of the royalty arrives for a meeting with a king. Without a specific story to attach it too, of course, it just becomes a generic scene.

The king sits with two of his consorts on the right of the panel inside a simple pavilion. In front of him, and at the same height, is his royal visitor sitting under a tree. Behind him is his entourage including a finely drawn elephant with its full regalia.
id: Kita punya beberapa adegan lain yang sering terlihat di dinding Borobudur: raja atau anggota keluarga kerajaan lain datang untuk bertemu dengan raja. Tanpa cerita khusus untuk menjelaskannya, tentu saja, itu hanya jadi adegan umum.

Raja duduk dengan dua pendampingnya di kanan panel, dalam anjungan sederhana. Di depannya, di ketinggian yang sama, ada pengunjung kerajaannya yang duduk di bawah pohon. Di belakangnya ada rombongannya, termasuk gajah yang dipahat halus dengan tanda kebesaran lengkap.

en: The scene in set in the wilderness with trees and many birds atop them. A king sits on a small horse in the centre of the relief, behind him an attendant holds a parasol over him, and behind him are more attendants and soldiers who hold arrows.

In front of the king is someone who appears to be pointing to the wild animals seen on the left of the relief. Presumably he is a guide. The animals include a couple of pigs, a deer and a pair of squirrels playing in the trees. In the top left corner we also see a monkey.
id: Adegan ditata di belantara dengan pepohonan dan banyak burung di atas. Raja duduk di atas kuda kecil di tengah relief, di belakangnya pelayan memegangi payung di atasnya, dan di belakang ada lebih banyak pelayan dan prajurit yang memegang panah.

Di depan raja ada seseorang yang tampak menunjuk hewan liar yang terlihat di kiri relief. Kemungkinan ia pemandu. Hewan-hewan itu termasuk sepasang babi, rusa, dan sepasang tupai yang bermain di pepohonan. Di sudut kiri atas kita juga lihat monyet.

en: On the right we see a very well drawn pavilion which is elaborately decorated. On a raised seat inside the king sits with his knee supported by a strap. He is looking back at his queen who sits behind him. At a lower level, and behind the queen, two attendants are pictured.

On the left a group of people sit on the floor, a number of whom hold their hands in añjali. They all have the same type of headband which probably signifies they are from a foreign kingdom. Above them are the regalia: a leaffan, a peacock-feather fan and a parasol.
id: Di kanan, kita lihat anjungan yang dipahat dengan sangat bagus dengan hiasan rumit. Di kursi tinggi di dalam, raja duduk dengan lutut ditopang bebat. Ia menengok ratu yang duduk di belakangnya. Di lantai yang lebih rendah, di belakang ratu, dua pelayan digambarkan.

Di kiri sekelompok orang duduk di lantai, beberapa di antaranya menangkupkan tangan. Mereka semua punya jenis ikat kepala sama yang mungkin menandakan mereka berasal dari kerajaan asing. Di atas mereka ada tanda kebesaran: kipas daun, kipas bulu merak, dan payung.

en: The whole scene is set outside under the trees and in rocky terrain. On the right are three men, two of whom hold weapons, and the third is leaning forward and pointing with his hand above his head. The role these three play is hard to know.

In the centre and on the left children are being saved from drowning, and being passed to people who carry them away on their hips, and towards the man who is pointing. On the far left is one boy who stands with his hand on his hip. He must be in the water also, but does not appear to be distressed like the others.
id: Seluruh adegan ditempatkan di luar di bawah pohon dan di lahan berbatu. Di kanan ada tiga lelaki, dua diantaranya pegang senjata, dan yang ketiga condong ke depan dan menunjuk dengan tangan di atas kepalanya. Peran yang dimainkan ketiganya sulit diketahui.

Di tengah dan di kiri, anak-anak diselamatkan dari tenggelam, dan diserahkan kepada orang-orang yang menggendong mereka di pinggul mereka, dan ke arah orang yang menunjuk. Di kiri jauh ada anak lelaki yang berdiri dengan tangan di pinggulnya. Ia seharusnya berada dalam air juga, tetapi tidak tampak tertekan seperti yang lain.

en: So many times on these reliefs we have a generic scene which I have designated ‘A Meeting with a King’ as we simply do not know what is taking place without a text to identify it. Here we have a variation, which is a meeting with a queen.

On the right the queen sits inside a very elaborate building and is making a gesture with her hand to the interlocutor who sits in a heavily decorated antechamber in front of her. Outside in a pavilion sit eleven members of his entourage. Notice the birds above both buildings.
id: Banyak kali pada relief-relief ini, kita mendapati adegan umum yang telah saya tetapkan sebagai “Pertemuan Dengan Raja” karena kita tidak tahu apa yang terjadi tanpa naskah untuk mengenalinya. Di sini kita punya ragam lain, yaitu pertemuan dengan ratu.

Di kanan, ratu duduk dalam bangunan yang sangat rumit dan membuat isyarat dengan tangannya mengulur ke teman bicara yang duduk di selasar yang sangat dihias di hadapannya. Di luar, dalam anjungan, duduk sebelas anggota rombongannya. Perhatikan burung di atas kedua bangunan.

en: This scene is set in the wilderness, with trees, a lake and birds populating it. In the middle sits a nāga who has apparently emerged from the waters where he lives.
On the right side we see a king in conversation with the nāga. The king and the nāga appear to be positioned at the same height. The king’s soldiers are behind him, holding swords of various kinds.
id: Adegan ini terletak di belantara, dengan pepohonan, danau, dan burung yang menghuninya. Di tengah, duduk naga yang tampak muncul dari air di mana ia tinggal.
Di sisi kanan kita lihat raja bicara dengan naga. Raja dan naga tampak ditempatkan di sama tinggi. Para prajurit raja ada di belakangnya, memegang berbagai jenis pedang.

en: This panel appears to be split into two, separated by the tree trunk in the middle. On the right, which would be seen first, and will therefore come earlier in the story, we see a brahmin sitting with some friends inside a simple building. Towards the centre sit the womenfolk.

On the left it appears the same character is now at the head of a delegation to the king, who sits inside a pavilion on a raised seat with his two consorts. There is a very well-drawn coconut tree above his companions, and birds are dotted about.
id: Panel ini tampak dibagi dua, dipisahkan dengan batang pohon di tengah. Di kanan, yang akan dilihat terlebih dahulu, dan karena itu akan muncul lebih awal dalam cerita, kita lihat brahmana duduk dengan beberapa teman dalam bangunan sederhana. Ke arah tengah, duduk kaum perempuan.

Di kiri, tampak sosok yang sama sekarang jadi kepala perwakilan untuk raja, yang duduk dalam anjungan di kursi tinggi dengan dua pendampingnya. Ada pohon kelapa yang dipahat sangat bagus di atas rombongan, dan burung bertebaran.

name.en: 99. A King flies in the Sky

en: Again the scene is in two parts. On the right it seems the advisors and soldiers of the king have accompanied the king to the edge of the wilderness where he stands with his hand held up making a gesture.

On the left what must be the same king and one of his advisors are flying away on a cloud beyond the trees that separate the scenes. Birds are seen in the treetops below them. Reliefs like this make one really want to know the story, which alas! we lack.
id: Lagi-lagi adegan dalam dua bagian. Di kanan tampak para penasihat dan prajurit raja menemani raja ke tepi belantara, tempat ia berdiri dengan tangan diangkat membuat isyarat.

Di kiri, pasti raja yang sama dan salah satu penasihatnya terbang di atas awan di atas pepohonan yang memisahkan adegan. Burung terlihat di puncak pohon di bawah mereka. Relief seperti ini membuat orang sungguh ingin tahu ceritanya, yang sayang, kita kurang tahu.

en: On the far right we see a very fine palatial building, with stairs in front of it, and clouds and a bird above it. The king, who is presumably the owner also, sits in front of his courtiers and is gesturing as he speaks.
On the left a brahmin sits on a seat at the same height as the king, and his courtiers behind him are holding regalia signifying that he is also a king. On the far left is a finely drawn elephant.
id: Di kanan jauh, kita lihat bangunan megah yang sangat indah, dengan tangga di depannya, awan dan burung di atasnya. Raja, yang mungkin juga pemiliknya, duduk di depan pegawainya dan memberi isyarat saat ia bicara.

Di kiri, brahmana duduk di kursi yang sama tinggi dengan raja, dan para pegawai kerajaan di belakangnya memegang tanda kebesaran yang menandakan bahwa ia juga raja. Di kiri jauh ada gajah yang dipahat bagus.

en: This is a rather unusual relief if I am reading it right, it is dominated by a meeting scene which takes place inside a small building in the middle of the panel. What is unusual is that the queen on the left seems to be situated higher than the king, who is worshipping her. In similar scenes where we can identify the characters the king is meeting with his mother, and it may be so here.
On the right are what looks like the king’s men, with swords held high, sitting under trees upon which birds perch. On the left appear to be the queen’s ladies-in-waiting also sitting under a tree.
id: Ini relief yang tidak biasa, jika saya membacanya dengan benar, yang didominasi oleh adegan pertemuan yang berlangsung dalam bangunan kecil di tengah panel. Yang tidak biasa, ratu di kiri tampak terletak lebih tinggi dari raja, yang menyembahnya. Dalam adegan serupa, di mana kita bisa mengenali sosok-sosoknya, raja menemui ibunya, mungkin begitu pula di sini.
Di kanan ada apa yang terlihat seperti prajurit raja, dengan pedang terangkat tinggi, duduk di bawah pohon tempat burung bertengger. Di kiri tampak para dayang ratu juga duduk di bawah pohon.

en: Another of the generic ‘meeting with a king’ scenes, this one differs slightly by being set in the wilderness. On the right is pictured a forest, with seemingly a queen sitting under a tree on the far right. Nearer the centre sit two people who have particularly sublime expressions on their faces.

The king, whose figure is quite worn, sits at ease inside a simple pavilion and may have been speaking. In front of him two people sit on the floor with their hands raised in salutation, and behind them three more stand with bows strung over their shoulders.
id: Lain dari adegan umum “pertemuan dengan raja”, yang satu ini sedikit berbeda karena bertempat di belantara. Di kanan digambarkan hutan, dengan ratu yang tampak duduk di bawah pohon di kanan jauh. Dekat ke tengah, duduk dua orang yang punya pancaran sungguh luhur di paras mereka.

Raja, yang sosoknya cukup rusak, duduk santai dalam anjungan sederhana dan mungkin sedang bicara. Di depannya, dua orang duduk di lantai dengan tangan terangkat menghormat, dan di belakang mereka berdiri tiga lagi dengan busur digantung di bahu mereka.

en: On the right two kings sit at ease inside a simple pavilion and appear to be in discussion. On the far right one attendant is holding something up, but what it is is hard to say. Above him is a coconut tree.

On the left are the usual mixture of courtiers, soldiers and attendants that accompany one of the kings. There is an elephant behind them, and the normal regalia: a peacock-feather fan, and a leaf-fan, but no parasol this time.
id: Di kanan dua raja duduk santai dalam anjungan sederhana dan tampak sedang bertukar pikiran. Di kanan jauh, satu pelayan memegang sesuatu, tetapi sulit dibilang itu apa. Di atasnya ada pohon kelapa.

Di kiri ada gabungan seperti biasa pegawai, prajurit, dan pelayan yang menemani salah satu raja. Ada gajah di belakang mereka, dan tanda kebesaran seperti biasa: kipas bulu merak, kipas daun, tapi tak ada payung kali ini.

en: Similar to 101 above we here see a king pictured as lower than the queen he is meeting with, inside a simple and rather plain building. The queen is shown as being much larger than the king, and much higher also.
On the right are the king’s soldiers bearing arms, and many attendants carrying offerings and bearing regalia. On the left the womenfolk of the queen’s court look on.
id: Serupa dengan panel 101 di atas, di sini kita lihat raja digambarkan lebih rendah daripada ratu yang ia temui, dalam bangunan sederhana dan agak polos. Ratu ditampilkan jauh lebih besar dari raja, dan jauh lebih tinggi juga.
Di kanan ada prajurit raja yang membawa senjata, dan banyak pelayan membawa persembahan dan tanda kebesaran. Di kiri, kaum perempuan dari istana ratu memandang.

en: In the centre we see a very elaborately decorated building and a member of the nobility, probably a king, sitting in meditation posture. Behind his head is a halo signifying that this is a Bodhisattva.
On the right are the courtiers and attendants holding the royal insignia, and on the left we see others, including a brahmin who is sitting near to the building and may be the king’s advisor.
id: Di tengah, kita lihat bangunan yang dihias sangat rumit dan anggota bangsawan, mungkin raja, duduk dalam postur meditasi. Di belakang kepalanya ada aura yang menandakan bahwa ia Bodhisattwa.
Di kanan ada para pegawai dan pelayan memegang lambang kerajaan, dan di kiri kita lihat yang lainnya, termasuk brahmana yang duduk di dekat bangunan dan mungkin penasihat raja.

background.en: The reliefs follow the Avadānaśataka (no 36) retelling of the story mainly. It is also known to the Divyāvadāna (no 38) and the Pāḷi Jātakas, but the latter has far less details and the main character is not the Bodhisattva, but a wicked man (Mittavinda, Ja 369).
background.id: Relief mengikuti Avadānaśataka (no. 36) yang mengisahkan kembali sebagian besar cerita itu. Cerita juga diketahui dalam Divyāvadāna (no. 38) dan Jātaka Pāḷi, namun yang Jātaka Pāḷi punya rincian yang jauh lebih sedikit dan pemeran utamanya bukanlah Bodhisattwa, tetapi orang jahat (Mittavinda, Ja 369).

en: A merchant had a son, the Bodhisattva in a previous life, but his father gave him a girl’s name, Maitrakanyaka. Before the boy had grown the merchant died while on the high seas. When the boy grew up he wanted to follow in his father’s footsteps and asked his mother what his occupation had been.

His mother, not wanting to lose her son, lied and told him his father had been a shopkeeper, a perfumer and a goldsmith in succession. He was successful at all these trades, and so much so the other goldsmiths, who were jealous of him, told him his father had been a merchant who sailed the high seas just to get rid of the competition.

Maitrakanyaka then had it announced he would lead an expedition abroad, and 500 merchants joined him. His mother tried to dissuade him from going, but he kicked her in the head, and left on his adventure. His ship was soon shipwrecked though, and he was separated from the others.

Maitrakanyaka came to the city of Ramaṇaka and was greeted by four divine maidens (apsaras) who invited him to stay with them. He lived there many years, but was curious about what lay south, and set out to find out. Then he came to Sadāmatta, which had eight apsaras, and later Nandana which had sixteen.

Still traveling south he came next to Brahmottara, which had thirty-two divine maidens, but still not satisfied he traveled once more south and came to the city of Ayomaya (Iron-Made). As soon as he entered, the doors slammed shut behind him, and as he went deeper in, he was unable to escape.

Eventually he came into the presence of a tall man whose head was crowned with a wheel which was fiery and tearing his head apart. Asking what the man had done to deserve such a fate he was told he had ill-treated his own mother, at which Maitrakanyaka remembered he had kicked his mother in the head, and the wheel jumped from the tall man’s head to his own.

He asked how long he would have to suffer like this, and was told it would last 60,600 years before someone else who had committed the same sort of deed would take his place. Stirred by compassion Maitrakanyaka made an aspiration that the wheel would never leave his own head and hurt another in the same way. As soon as he made that aspiration the wheel flew away from his head and he was immediately reborn in Tuṣita Heaven.
id: Pedagang punya seorang putra, Bodhisattwa pada kehidupan lampau, tapi ayahnya memberinya nama perempuan, Maitrakanyaka. Sebelum anak itu dewasa, sang pedagang meninggal tatkala di laut lepas. Ketika anak itu tumbuh, ia ingin mengikuti jejak ayahnya dan bertanya kepada ibunya apa pekerjaan ayahnya.

Ibunya, tak ingin kehilangan putranya, berbohong dan berkata kepadanya bahwa ayahnya adalah penjaga toko, pembuat wewangian, dan pandai emas, berturutan. Ia berhasil dalam semua perdagangan ini, sehingga banyak pandai emas lainnya, yang iri padanya, memberi tahu bahwa ayahnya adalah pedagang yang mengarungi laut lepas, sekadar untuk menyingkirkan persaingan.

Maitrakanyaka lalu mengumumkan bahwa ia akan memimpin perjalanan ke negeri lain, dan 500 pedagang bergabung dengannya. Ibunya berusaha mencegahnya untuk pergi, tetapi ia malah menendang kepala ibunya, dan pergi bertualang. Namun, kapalnya tak lama karam, dan ia terpisah dari yang lain.

Maitrakanyaka tiba di Kota Ramaṇaka dan disambut empat bidadari surga (apsara) yang mengundangnya tinggal bersama mereka. Ia tinggal di sana bertahun-tahun, namun penasaran tentang apa yang ada di selatan, dan berangkat untuk mencari tahu. Lalu ia datang ke Sadāmatta, yang punya delapan apsara, lalu Nandana yang punya enam belas apsara.
Masih bepergian ke selatan, ia tiba di Brahmottara, yang punya tiga puluh dua bidadari surga, namun masih belum puas, ia melakukan perjalanan

sekali lagi ke selatan dan tiba di Kota Ayomaya (Terbuat dari Besi). Begitu ia masuk, pintu di belakangnya terbanting tertutup, dan saat ia masuk lebih dalam, ia tak bisa kabur. Akhirnya ia tiba di hadapan lelaki tinggi yang kepalanya dimahkotai roda api yang menyala dan mencabik kepalanya. Bertanya apa yang telah dilakukan lelaki itu sehingga bernasib demikian, Maitrakanyaka diberi tahu bahwa ia telah memperlakukan ibunya sendiri dengan buruk, yang membuat Maitrakanyaka teringat ia telah menendang kepala ibunya, dan roda itu melompat dari kepala lelaki tinggi itu ke kepalanya.

Ia bertanya berapa lama ia harus menderita seperti ini, dan diberi tahu bahwa itu akan berlangsung 60.600 tahun sebelum orang lain yang melakukan tindakan yang sama akan menggantikannya. Tergerak oleh welas asih, Maitrakanyaka membuat tekad bahwa roda itu tidak akan pernah meninggalkan kepalanya sendiri dan melukai orang lain dengan cara yang sama. Begitu ia membuat tekad itu, roda terbang menjauh dari kepalanya dan ia seketika terlahir ulang di Surga Tuṣita.

en: When Maitrakanyaka had grown up he asked his mother about his father’s occupation, and was first told he had been a shopkeeper, and later that he had been a perfumer. He took up the trades and at the end of the day offered the money he had made to his mother.

Maitrakanyaka sits inside a pavilion with his mother, who is positioned much higher then he is. He has a money bag in front of him which he is offering to her. On the far left is a building, perhaps meant to signify the city where he had been working.
id: Ketika Maitrakanyaka telah dewasa, ia bertanya kepada ibunya tentang pekerjaan ayahnya, dan pertama kali diberi tahu bahwa ayahnya adalah penjaga toko, lalu ia menjadi pembuat wewangian. Maitrakanyaka menjalani perdagangan itu dan pada akhir hari mempersembahkan uang yang ia hasilkan kepada ibunya.

Maitrakanyaka duduk dalam anjungan bersama ibunya, yang ditempatkan jauh lebih tinggi darinya. Ia punya kantong uang di depannya yang ia persembahkan kepada ibunya. Di kiri jauh ada bangunan, mungkin dimaksudkan untuk menandakan kota tempat ia bekerja.

name.id: 107. Bekerja Sebagai Pandai Emas dan Berangkat

en: Next Maitrakanyaka worked as a goldsmith, but was so good at the trade that other goldsmiths got jealous and informed him of his father’s true occupation. He therefore gave up that trade also and set forth to become a merchant on the high seas, but not before he kicked his mother in the head as she tried to prevent him.

The panel is in two sections. On the right we first see Maitrakanyaka plying his trade as a goldsmith, he sits on the far right and is engaged with his customers who sit in front of him. The building near the middle acts as a divider. On the left we see him departing with another man. In front of him his mother is down on her knees pleading with him not to go.
id: Selanjutnya Maitrakanyaka bekerja sebagai pandai emas, namun sangat pandai berdagang, sehingga pandai emas lain iri dan memberitahunya mengenai pekerjaan ayahnya yang sebenarnya. Ia karenanya berhenti perdagangan itu juga dan mantap untuk menjadi pedagang di laut lepas, tetapi setelah ia menendang kepala ibunya ketika berusaha mencegahnya.

Panel dibagi dua. Di kanan kita pertama lihat Maitrakanyaka menjalani perdagangannya sebagai pandai emas, ia duduk di kanan jauh dan terlibat dengan para pelanggan yang duduk di hadapannya. Bangunan di dekat tengah berperan sebagai penyekat. Di kiri kita lihat Maitrakanyaka pergi dengan orang lain. Di depannya, ibunya berlutut memohon agar ia tidak pergi.

name.en: 108. The Ship and the Four Apsaras

en: In the Avadānaśataka story after Maitrakanyaka sets sail the ship is upturned by a makara fish and clinging to a plank of wood he makes it to shore. None of this is portrayed on the relief, and the sculptors may have known a different version of the story at this point. He eventually came to the city of Ramaṇaka where he was greeted by four divine nymphs (apsaras).

Again the scene is divided into two. On the right we see the finely-drawn ship sailing the high seas with its masts and sails held high. In front of it another boat seems to be grappling with some problem. On the right Maitrakanyaka has landed and is greeted by four well-dressed apsaras who will entertain him for many years.
id: Dalam cerita Avadānaśataka, setelah Maitrakanyaka berlayar, kapal digulingkan oleh ikan makara, dan berpegangan di papan kayu ia berhasil ke pantai. Tak satu pun ini digambarkan pada relief, dan para perupa mungkin telah mengetahui ragam cerita yang berbeda pada titik ini. Maitrakanyaka akhirnya tiba di Kota Ramaṇaka, tempat ia disambut oleh empat bidadari surga (apsara).

Lagi-lagi adegan dibagi dua. Di kanan kita lihat kapal yang dipahat indah berlayar di laut lepas dengan tiang dan layar terangkat tinggi. Di depannya ada perahu lain yang tampaknya sedang bergulat dengan masalah. Di kanan, Maitrakanyaka mendarat dan disambut oleh empat apsara berbusana indah yang akan menghiburnya selama bertahun-tahun.

en: The apsaras at Ramaṇaka always tried to dissuade Maitrakanyaka from going south of the city, which made him want to go there even more. Eventually he decided to go and he came to another city, Sadāmatta, where he was greeted by eight divine maidens more lovely than the ones he had left behind.

Surprisingly, we see nothing of the city, and indeed the scene is set in the wilderness. It is hard to know whether this represents a variation in the telling of the story. Maitrakanyaka stands on the right and sitting before him are the eight apsaras. The landscape is dotted with birds and animals.
id: Para apsara di Ramaṇaka selalu berusaha untuk mencegah Maitrakanyaka agar tidak pergi ke selatan kota, yang malah membuatnya makin ingin pergi ke sana. Akhirnya Maitrakanyaka memutuskan untuk pergi dan ia tiba di kota lain, Sadāmatta, di mana ia disambut oleh delapan bidadari surga yang lebih menyenangkan daripada yang ia tinggalkan.

Anehnya, kita tidak melihat apa pun di kota ini, dan pasti adegan bertempat di belantara. Sulit untuk tahu apakah ini mewakili ragam lain dalam penuturan cerita. Maitrakanyaka berdiri di kanan dan duduk di hadapannya delapan bidadari. Pemandangan dipenuhi dengan burung dan binatang.

en: After enjoying himself at Sadāmatta for many years Maitrakanyaka once again headed south, and met with sixteen nymphs in the city of Nandana, where he again took up residence.

On the relief we see only eleven apsaras, though it would easily have been possible to fit in sixteen if the sculptors wished. It may represent another variation, or it may just be a whim of the designers. Four are seen standing and seven are sitting. Again the scene is set in the countryside, not in the city.
id: Setelah bersenang-senang di Sadāmatta selama bertahun-tahun, Maitrakanyaka sekali lagi menuju ke selatan, dan bertemu dengan enam belas bidadari di Kota Nandana, tempat ia kembali menetap.

Di relief kita hanya melihat sebelas apsara, walau mungkin dengan mudah bisa memuat enam belas jika perupa mau. Ini mungkin mewakili ragam lainnya, atau mungkin hanya kemauan para perancang. Empat terlihat berdiri dan tujuh duduk. Lagi-lagi adegan bertempat di perdesaan, bukan di kota.

en: After some time Maitrakanyaka, driven by his curiosity and desire, set off again for the south and came to Brahmottara where he was greeted by thirty-two divine nymphs.

It may have been the difficulty of fitting such a large number on the panel that drove the sculptors to start curtailing their number on the last reliefs. Here, anyway, we see only fourteen. One stands besides Maitrakanyaka and the others sit and stand on the left of the relief.
id: Setelah beberapa waktu, Maitrakanyaka, didorong oleh rasa ingin tahu dan hasrat, berangkat lagi ke selatan dan tiba di Brahmottara, tempat ia disambut oleh tiga puluh dua bidadari surga.

Mungkin sulit untuk menempatkan sejumlah besar bidadari dalam panel, yang mendorong para perupa untuk mulai membatasi jumlah mereka di relief terakhir. Di sini, bagaimanapun, kita hanya melihat empat belas. Satu berdiri di samping Maitrakanyaka dan yang lainnya duduk dan berdiri di kiri relief.

en: Traveling again south Maitrakanyaka came to the city made of iron, and as he entered the door shut behind him. He saw a tall man with a fiery wheel which was cutting his head open. Learning the punishment was because of ill-treating his mother, Maitrakanyaka remembered his own wicked deed, and the wheel then descended onto his head. After vowing that he would wear the wheel, and no one else should ever suffer like he was suffering, he was reborn in Tuṣita Heaven because of his compassion.

There are two scenes in this panel: on the far right we see the tall man with the wheel cutting his head. Maitrakanyaka stands in front and is in conversation with a rakṣasa who reveals the reason for the man’s suffering. A small building stands in the middle and divides the scene. On the left Maitrakanyaka has already been reborn in Tuṣita Heaven and is enjoying the fruits of his compassion.
id: Bepergian lagi ke selatan, Maitrakanyaka tiba di kota yang terbuat dari besi, dan saat ia masuk, pintu di belakangnya menutup. Ia melihat lelaki jangkung dengan roda api yang membelah kepalanya. Mengetahui hukumannya dikarenakan memperlakukan ibunya dengan buruk, Maitrakanyaka teringat perbuatan jahatnya sendiri, dan roda meluncur ke kepalanya. Setelah bersumpah bahwa ia akan menanggung roda itu, sehingga tidak ada orang lain yang akan menderita seperti dirinya, Maitrakanyaka terlahir ulang di Surga Tuṣita karena welas asihnya.

Ada dua adegan di panel ini: di kanan jauh kita lihat lelaki jangkung dengan roda membelah kepalanya. Maitrakanyaka berdiri di depannya dan bercakap dengan raksasa yang menyingkap sebab penderitaan lelaki itu. Bangunan kecil berdiri di tengah dan menyekat adegan.
